text: [Music]
my interest has always been in the
influence process how it is that people
can be spurred to say yes to a request
uh even one that they might not be
interested in in its merits uh the way I
got into it is actually something more
personal uh I always been a sucker
always been a a py for the um pitches of
salespeople or fundraisers who've come
to my door so I've wound up in unwanted
possession of uh of tickets to the
sanitation workers's ball and and and
uh uh magazine subscriptions that I
didn't really want and and I always
wondered how could that be I didn't want
these things yet I wound up purchasing
them there must be a psychology to the
presentation that's separate from the
merits of the thing so I began to study
the influence process uh systematically
first in my role as a uh a behavioral
scientist uh but then uh taking a
broader look I actually infiltrated the
training programs of as many influence
professions that I could get access to I
tried to learn how to sell autom mobiles
from a lot uh vacuum cleaners door Todo
uh portrait photography over the phone I
was the guy from Oland Mills I was that
guy uh I didn't stop there I also looked
at what the fundraisers were doing to
get us to say yes what advertising
copywriters were doing what lobbyists
were doing even
recruiters uh armed service recruiters
corporate recruiters I even studied what
cult recruiters do get us to say yes and
through it all I looked for those
commonalities which were the things that
were being used in common in parallel
across all of the people who were
interested in getting us to say yes to
their
requests certainly you have you you
always stand on the the shoulders of
giants and for example um Stanley
Milgram who did the famous Milgram uh
obedience research who showed how uh
people would respond to the uh
directives of an authority figure to
deliver nearly fatal levels of shock to
an innocent other person simply because
they were commanded to do it by someone
in a white coat carrying a clipboard and
professing to be a scientist professing
to be someone who was in Authority in
the the lab situation where they were
working and people very many of them I
indeed 65% were willing to deliver all
the available shocks that were were were
uh uh there in the situation for them to
use simply because they were directed to
do so that's a very powerful
psychological phenomenon other people uh
for example uh Leon festinger who
studied something called cognitive
dissonance theory the desire of people
to be consistent with what they've
already said and done even if it doesn't
make sense in uh the larger sense but in
that particular situation in order for
them to be consistent with what they've
already said or done in public they will
do what seems to be irrational things uh
uh Philip zimbardo who did the famous uh
Stanford prison experiment in which he
showed how putting Stanford
undergraduates in the role of prisoner
or guard caus them just by virtue of the
situation to start taking on the
characteristics and the behaviors of
those
problematic uh uh situations that we
find in our prisons uh prisoners ganging
up on one another guards abusing the
prisoners and so on uh this sort of
thing emerged just because the situation
was there not because of the kind of
people who were there you can put
anybody in those situations and you get
uh what what surface is to be uh very
alarming they reenacted it can't be done
um with real subjects any longer because
um uh it was so um devastating to a lot
of the people who participated they saw
themselves being pawns and being willing
to deliver nearly deadly levels of
electric shock to someone simply because
they were commanded to do so by somebody
who they didn't know um that left some
of these people uh sufficiently uh in
doubt of their own self-confidence and
and ethics uh that it can't be done
anymore the uh uh American Psychological
Association won't allow that kind of
research to be done
